__data__.text: The Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) established its Alaska chapters in Anchorage and Fairbanks in 1982, following a merger with the Brothers MC. The Alaskan Hells Angels have been involved in methamphetamine trafficking. In 1985, an Alaska Hells Angels member became an FBI informant, leading to the arrest of 38 HAMC members in Alaska and four other states in 1987. In 2003, four Alaskan Hells Angels were arrested on federal racketeering and firearms charges, resulting in the conviction of six members in 2006. Violent incidents involving Hells Angels have occurred in Alaska, including a murder in 2017 linked to a white supremacist prison gang. In Arizona, the HAMC is classified as a criminal street gang and is involved in methamphetamine production and distribution. The Hells Angels established six Arizona chapters after merging with the Dirty Dozen in 1997. Operation Black Biscuit, an undercover investigation by the ATF, resulted in the arrest of two Hells Angels members in Arizona in 2001 for narcotics trafficking.

The Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) has established chapters in Alaska and Arizona, where they have been involved in methamphetamine trafficking and other criminal activities. In Arizona, the HAMC formed a partnership with an individual named Kramer, who claimed to be arming the Solo Angeles in Mexico to combat a Mongols chapter there. Kramer helped the HAMC form a Solo Angeles nomads chapter in Arizona, which the ATF used to make contact with the Hells Angels. Kramer's role as an informant was later exposed, and he was sentenced to five years in prison. In 2003, a series of synchronized raids were carried out across Arizona, resulting in the arrests of fifty-two people and the seizure of over 500 illegal weapons. The investigation, known as Operation Black Biscuit, was deemed a success by the ATF, but internal government disagreement ultimately led to the sixteen defendants escaping conviction on key charges. The Hells Angels have been involved in various violent incidents in Arizona, including the murder of Cynthia Garcia in 2001 and the shooting of Joshua William Harber in 2002. The conflict with the Mongols motorcycle club has also led to several violent incidents, including the shooting of Daniel Leroy "Hoover" Seybert in 2003 and the killing of Richard "AZ Slick" Garcia in 2016.

The Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) has been involved in various violent incidents and criminal activities, including methamphetamine trafficking and firearms charges. In Arizona, the HAMC formed a partnership with an individual named Kramer, who helped them form a Solo Angeles nomads chapter. This led to a series of synchronized raids in 2003, resulting in the arrests of fifty-two people and the seizure of over 500 illegal weapons. However, internal government disagreement led to the dismissal of charges against thirty-six defendants. The HAMC has been involved in conflicts with other motorcycle clubs, such as the Mongols and Vagos, leading to several violent incidents and arrests. The club has also been linked to murders, including the killing of Cynthia Garcia in 2001, Patrick Michael Eberhardt in 2015, Richard "AZ Slick" Garcia in 2016, and Randall Scott Pfeil in 2010. The HAMC has been labeled a gang in Arizona, with members involved in various criminal activities and illegal enterprises. The club has a significant presence in California, Colorado, and Nevada, with violent incidents reported in these states.

The Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) has been involved in various violent incidents and criminal activities, including shootings, assaults, and drug trafficking. In Colorado, a prospective member named Lockhart was charged with attempted murder and other crimes after firing at vehicles in a road rage incident and hitting a police car. He was later convicted of vehicular eluding and acquitted of attempted murder. In 2019, HAMC members were involved in a gun battle in Arvada, leaving one person dead and three injured. The club's Denver chapter clubhouse was raided by police in 2001, leading to a lawsuit and a $50,000 settlement. In 2005, two HAMC members were arrested for possession of handguns after being pulled over for speeding, resulting in a federal lawsuit and a settlement. In 2018, a HAMC member sued the city of Greeley and several police departments after a police officer joked about shooting him during a traffic stop, leading to a $25,000 settlement. In 2019, twelve people were taken into custody in a organized crime case involving the Denver Hells Angels chapter, including members charged with assault, kidnapping, and drug trafficking. The club has also been linked to murders in various states, including Connecticut where the Bridgeport chapter has been recruited as enforcers for the Mafia. The chapter has been involved in several violent incidents, including a shooting in 1975 that left a police officer critically injured and the arrest of five members for manslaughter in connection with the death of José Sosa.

The Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) has been involved in various violent incidents and criminal activities, including murders, assaults, and drug trafficking. In Connecticut, the Bridgeport chapter has been particularly notorious, with members being charged and convicted of manslaughter, assault, and extortion. In 1975, five members were arrested for the manslaughter of José Sosa, who was beaten to death after a near collision with a biker. In 1980, Joseph Whelan was sentenced to 25 years to life for fatally stabbing a bar patron, and in 1998, Daniel "Dan" Klimas was sentenced to 28 years for murdering a rejected club prospect. In 2006, Roger Mariani was shot and killed, and another member was wounded, in an altercation with four men on the Connecticut Turnpike. In 2010, Joseph "HoJo" Ferraiolo, the president of the Outlaws' Waterbury chapter, was murdered, and the Hells Angels are considered suspects. In 2016, Howard Hammer, an associate of the club, was sentenced to two-and-a-half years for his involvement in an extortion scheme. Additionally, in 1985, 37 members and associates of the Bridgeport Hells Angels were arrested on racketeering and drug trafficking charges in connection with a three-year FBI investigation known as Operation Roughrider.

The Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) has been involved in various violent incidents and criminal activities, including murders, assaults, drug trafficking, and bomb plots. In several instances, law enforcement officers have been injured during raids and investigations of the club. For example, in Operation Roughrider, an undercover FBI agent infiltrated the club for over two years, resulting in the arrests of 133 members and associates and the seizure of large quantities of drugs and weapons. In another incident, four leading members of the Hells Angels in northern Illinois were arrested and charged with numerous crimes, including violating the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations (RICO) Act. In addition, the club has been involved in retaliation attempts against law enforcement officers and has collaborated with other criminal organizations. The Hells Angels have established chapters in several states and have been the most significant motorcycle gang involved in drug trafficking in Massachusetts. Violent incidents involving the club have resulted in injuries to both club members and law enforcement officers.

The Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) has been involved in various violent incidents and criminal activities, including murders, assaults, drug trafficking, and collaborations with other criminal organizations. Specific instances of their violent behavior include kidnapping, assault, and mayhem. For example, HAMC members kidnapped and severely beat Theodore Condon, and later assaulted a woman at a clubhouse. HAMC members have also been accused of murdering a member of a rival club and wounding another in a shooting and stabbing incident. In addition, conflicts with rival clubs have resulted in serious injuries and deaths. HAMC members have been convicted of possessing firearms and ammunition, and have been sentenced to prison for their crimes. The club has also been linked to unsolved murders, including the killing of a Hells Angels prospect and the disappearance of the prospect's girlfriend.

The Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) has been involved in various criminal activities, including murders, assaults, drug trafficking, and collaborations with other criminal organizations. Specific instances of their violent behavior include a brawl involving approximately 50 members of the Hells Angels and the Pagans, resulting in seven members being stabbed. The club has been linked to unsolved murders, such as the killing of a Hells Angels prospect and his girlfriend, and the murder of a drug dealer over a cocaine deal. HAMC members have been arrested for firearms charges and racketeering. The club has taken over loansharking and drug dealing activities from the Patriarca crime family's Boston faction.

The Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) has been involved in various criminal activities, including murders, assaults, drug trafficking, and collaborations with other criminal organizations. In 1996, sixteen members and associates were arrested during raids in Salem, and convicted for selling cocaine and methamphetamine. In 1997 and 1998, Domey and Bartolomeo were sentenced to 20 and 35 years in prison respectively for their involvement in the criminal enterprise. In 1986, two members were arrested on firearms charges as part of Operation One Percenter. In 1987, Hells Angels member Mark "Rebel" McKenna was indicted for operating the largest loansharking ring in US history. In 2007, a joint investigation by ATF, DEA, MSP and IRS resulted in the arrests of six club members on various charges. In April 2022, a shooting occurred at the clubhouse in Springfield, Missouri, and two men were arrested. The Hells Angels are also involved in retail-level methamphetamine distribution in Nebraska, where they have been linked to various violent incidents and murders since the 1960s. The club has taken over ancillary activities of the Patriarca crime family's Boston faction, such as loansharking and drug dealing. The club has been involved in drug trafficking, including heroin and methamphetamine, in Omaha since the 1960s. The club has used intimidation, assault, torture and murder to establish a monopoly of the methamphetamine trade in the Omaha area.

In the 1970s and 1980s, the Hells Angels were involved in various criminal activities, including drug trafficking and violence, in several states, including Nebraska, California, and Minnesota. In Nebraska, members of the Omaha chapter obtained heroin from other chapters and sold it to undercover agents. In 1981, ten members and associates of the Omaha chapter were indicted for their role in a conspiracy to monopolize the methamphetamine trade in the area through intimidation, assault, torture, and murder. In 1983, a federal grand jury indicted 43 individuals, many of them Hells Angels, in connection with a cocaine distribution network in the Omaha metropolitan area. In 1985, an undercover FBI agent infiltrated the club, resulting in the indictments of 133 Hells Angels members and associates in eleven states on narcotics trafficking and racketeering charges. In 1990, fifteen Hells Angels members and associates were arrested in the Omaha area on charges including racketeering, money laundering, and weapons possession. In 2002, members of the Hells Angels and the Mongols motorcycle clubs fought each other at a casino in Laughlin, Nevada, resulting in three deaths. In 2010, an innocent bystander was wounded during a fight involving the Hells Angels, Outlaws, and Milford and Company Motorcycle Club in Manchester, New Hampshire. In 2017, Hells Angels member James Cunningham was arrested and sentenced to prison for methamphetamine trafficking in New Hampshire. The Hells Angels have also been involved in conflicts with other motorcycle clubs, including the Breed and the Devil's Disciples.

The Hells Angels, a notorious motorcycle club, have a history of criminal activities including drug trafficking, violence, and conflicts with rival clubs. In the 1970s and 1980s, they were involved in criminal activities in various states, including Nebraska, California, Minnesota, New Hampshire, and New Jersey. In New Hampshire, the Hells Angels formed their first chapter in 2000 and have been involved in various criminal activities, including a shootout with the New Jersey State Police in 2002 and a fight with rival clubs in 2010 that resulted in an innocent bystander being wounded. In 2017, Hells Angels member James Cunningham was arrested and sentenced to prison for methamphetamine trafficking. The club has also been linked to mafia connections and has been involved in rape, sexual assault, and murder. The club's activities have resulted in various investigations and arrests by law enforcement agencies.

The Hells Angels established their first chapter in North Carolina in 1973, led by Michael Franklin "Thunder" Finazzo, who helped the club gain control over the state's criminal rackets. Finazzo and his lieutenant were found murdered in 1981, likely due to a feud with the Outlaws or internal power struggle. The club's activities in North Carolina included drug trafficking, prostitution, and motorcycle theft. The Charlotte chapter was once the largest on the east coast but was disbanded after becoming precarious due to the murders and imprisonments.

In Oregon, the Hells Angels have avoided the state since 1967 due to an agreement with the Gypsy Jokers. However, a Hells Angels prospect was convicted of quadruple murder in 1994 in Gaston, connected to the club's Vallejo, California chapter.

In Pennsylvania, the Hells Angels have historically been prevented from establishing a presence in the Philadelphia area due to an alliance between the Pagans and the Philadelphia crime family. There have been various incidents of violence and property destruction linked to the rivalry between the two clubs. A Hells Angels chapter was formed in West Philadelphia in 2004, leading to tensions and conflicts with the Pagans. The Philadelphia Hells Angels chapter was eventually disbanded in 2005 following these conflicts.

The Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) established a chapter in North Carolina in 1973, engaging in criminal activities such as drug trafficking, prostitution, and motorcycle theft. The club's chapter in Charlotte was once the largest on the east coast but was disbanded due to murders and imprisonments. In Oregon, the Hells Angels have avoided the state since 1967 due to an agreement with the Gypsy Jokers. In Pennsylvania, the club's presence in Philadelphia has been prevented by an alliance between the Pagans and the Philadelphia crime family. In 2004, a Hells Angels chapter was formed in West Philadelphia, leading to conflicts with the Pagans and resulting in the chapter's disbandment in 2005. The Hells Angels have a working relationship with the Providence faction of the Patriarca crime family in Rhode Island. In South Carolina, the club has been involved in various criminal activities, including drug dealing, money laundering, and firearms trafficking. In Virginia, four New York metropolitan area Hells Angels members and one prospect were convicted of ambushing and wounding two southern Virginia-based Pagans members in 2018. The Hells Angels founded a Washington state Nomads chapter in 1994, and in 2001, a former Hells Angel and two others were convicted of murdering a man who had falsely claimed to be a member of the club.
